data.title: Introduce event on input to indicate dirty state change
data.body: Instead of firing this event around globally it should be emitted from the input itself.

data.title: VSCode: Not responding overnight on Linux
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version:RHEL 7 (kernel 3.10.0)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a repository and keep a JS file open overnight
2. Next morning you'll get the "Not responding, Reopen" message

Clicking reopen doesn't help. I actually have to shut down and restart again. This is the VSCode Linux version - to be clear.

data.title: can i customize the  default includepath in .vscode?
data.body:
I am using ubuntu 16.04 and the default includePath of Linux is always '/usr/include'. 
I have always to add '/usr/include/c++/5.x' to the path manually.
Is there any way to modify the default includePath?
thx!

data.title: Clicking on the gutter closes peek definition window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the peek definition window on a variable
2. Set and remove breakpoints inside the peek window.

It doesn't do it always, but randomly will close the peek window when setting and removing breakpoints.

Steps to Reproduce:

There is some kind of highlight happening where it is peeking the definition.

data.title: Javascript highlighting
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:
![unnamed](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13858505/15593349/0753f4b4-23b4-11e6-92bd-aa73baaef5eb.png)
1. When i write this kind of code, part of it is highlighted as green
2. Example if i write `var testing = test ? console.log('true') : console.log('false')` it highlights text after **:**

data.title: Installing an extension never completes
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version:Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Try to install Markdown Lint or Sean's Spell checker
2. The installation never completes and the icon stays in the wavy animation.
   If you stop VS Code and restart the extensions are not installed.

This doesn't seem to be an issue with Theme or snippet extensions.

data.title: Mouse pointer should not go away from editor when user perform action on error\info pop-up or debug action widget.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows

I am not certain if this is due to technical limitation or real issue but some time feel annoying.

With the current application behavior whenever user click on any dynamic control like error or info pp-up or "Debug action widget" then mouse pointer is not set back to original position on editor from where user left the control. 
If you compare the behavior with visual studio where after terminating the debug session mouse pointer set back to proper position (Line number).

Consider the scenario where user working in portrait mode to cover most of the screen portion with editor then it is annoying to find out the pointer location each time after clicking on the pop-up (error\info\debug)

![mousepointerissuenew](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/15592597/dd9cd550-2359-11e6-8a8f-9330e39eeef6.gif)

data.title: Integrated terminal should be able to bring up right click menu anywhere
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open integrated terminal
2. Right click in the terminal

The only place to bring up the paste option is on the text cursor. I think either right clicking inside terminal should paste (the same as Command Prompt) or be able to bring up that context menu anywhere inside the terminal.

data.title: Integrated terminal sometimes scrolls right after paste
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open integrated terminal
2. Type git clone 
3. Right click just to the right of the typing cursor
4. Paste https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-smoketest-express.git 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/15592020/61d125ba-2355-11e6-9dad-1b8cc1fe6744.png)

After scrolling back using the left arrow on the keypad, you cant get all the way back:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/15592051/8a311952-2355-11e6-8c9f-296dc17fb65c.png)

data.title: Getting error message "cannot find the module 'eslint-plugin-react' when opening .js.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.2.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows

I observed when I am opening any .js from my project folder I an getting error pop-up "Failed to load plugin react: cannot find the module 'eslint-plugin-react'.
I didn't understand why should user get this error message and what action they need to take to fix it. Error message it is not clear to the user whether they need to perform any manual action like install extension or any package.

![eslint-error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/15591862/74e9dbac-2354-11e6-8ba6-433f74a42904.gif)

data.title: Option to hide the status bar implemented
data.body: This fixes #6356

data.title: [API] Provide Virtual Document in window.visibleEditors or similar
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1-insiders
- OS Version: Win10

I know window.visibleEditors is supposed to contain actual text editors but it is not possible to tell at the moment if a VirtualDocument (ie a htmlContentProvider) is in view.

The scenario I would need this for is for detecting if a Virtual Document has focus when a command is triggered. If there is another work around for this please let me know.

Thanks :smile:

data.title: Lint showing error under variable name if an extra semicolon
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the smoke test repo
2. Open routes/index.js
3. Run build task

![linterrorsemicolon](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/15589456/d7bb06e6-2347-11e6-9e15-f1f717d4efde.PNG)

If there is a semicolon error, it will show an error under the variable if it is next to one. If the extra semicolon is next to a bracket, it shows under the semicolon. Shouldn't it always show under the semicolon?

data.title: Integrated terminal should be able to be recreated once exiting with bad error code
Glob regex matches too much
data.body:
`glob.match("**/project.json",...)` results in the regexp `(?:[/\\].*?|.+?[/\\]|)project\.json`

The or segment is strange `[/\\].*?`.
This results in `/rrproject.json` to be matched

data.title: cmder no longer works on integrated terminal and spams external cmder instances
data.body: Pretty sure ti was at one point, now it's opening a bunch of issues repeatedly as they exit with exit code 0.

data.title: cmder's prompt uses weird escape sequences that are not recognized by term.js
data.body: For example `{lamb}` converts into the lambda symbol in the default prompt.

data.title: Integrated terminal configured to use cmder doesn't open at correct directory
data.body: cmder will set itself as `%comspec%` once installed so it becomes the default automatically.

data.title: Support Live Reloading Scenarios

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
We'd like VS Code and the Node Debugger to support Live Reloading Scenarios. The current behavior is preventing React-Native users from having a good experience: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-react-native/issues/74

Currently it's not supported so modifying breakpoints while the program is running can have weird results (Breakpoints set in one line, appear in another line, or get deleted completely).

Things that we'd like to be supported are:
- Be able to edit a file in memory, and set a brekpoint before saving the file, so if there is any source map associated at all with this file at all, it'll map to the wrong thing, so VS Code would need to Remember the line where the breakpoint was set, and wait until the proper source map was loaded before actually setting the breakpoint.
- Be able to edit a file, save it, and set breakpoints before the recompilation process is finished, so initially it'll be associated with the wrong source map.
- The red and greyed out stop signs for the breakpoints should correctly indicate if the breakpoints were successfully installed.
- Editing a source file with breakpoints should result in intuitive results when adding lines before, or after the breakpoints, or even on the same line.

data.title: Provide way for extensions to download and install native dependencies

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: Any

This is a request for the [C# Extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.csharp). Essentially, the extension needs platform-specific native binaries in order to function (both for debugging support and OmniSharp for language server support). It does this by acquiring the binaries during the extension's first activation, rather than during installation. So, the user experience for installation is a bit awkward:
1. Install C# Extension
2. VS Code prompts to restart after successful installation
3. User restarts VS Code and opens a C# project
4. User waits after the "installed" extension finishes installing itself by acquiring native dependencies

To make matters worse, in order to acquire the native dependencies, the extension essentially has to copy code from VS Code in order to handle HTTP proxies correctly (see https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode/commit/b8f01e4dffd3e1208e08ded719f09c365416f9b1).

data.title: [json] Json Schema Server?

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Would be possible to get a editor agnostic Json Schema npm package or something we can use as a service?  Something similar to OmniSharp but for Json Schema I suppose.  Ideally it would also be able to be hosted independent of VSCode, so editors like Sublime could call on the same functionality as well.

All the hard work is done to get Json Schema support into VSCode, and I'm looking to derive from it to enhance the Atom support for Json Schema (and Json in general).  Now that said that means two duplicate code bases, doing essentially the same thing.  It would be great if we had one shared code base, so fixes could be shared amoung many editors.

Having a set of API's that could API's for...
- completion
- hover
- symbols
- formatting
- contributions
  - list
  - add
  - [remove?]

data.title: Menu items not localized
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version:Windows 8.1, OS X

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Configure Language to anything beside english
2. Restart VS Code

The top menu items and their dropdowns are not localized (show as English). The status bar, view bar and command palette show the correct localized strings.

This repros whether you are on a localized OS or not.

data.title: vscode.OpenFolder command does not work for Insider version
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1-insider
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:

When I use the new command `vscode.openFolder` provided in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/58 in the **Insider** version, instead of opening another **Insider** instance (or replacing the current one), it _always_ opens the **Stable**.

```
  vscode.commands.executeCommand('vscode.openFolder', uri, openInNewWindow)
```

Thanks for your help

data.title: Feature request: word wrapping config by document type
data.body:
I always want markdown word-wrapped wrapped. I never want most other files wrapped. So I find myself switching back and forth all the time.

It seems like there is already some document-type specific configuration for html, e.g.

```
// Maximum amount of characters per line (0 = disable).
"html.format.wrapLineLength": 120,
```

The universal setting is named differently:

```
"editor.wrappingColumn": 300,
```

It would be great if this convention were just standardized and applicable to any document type, and I could use `markdown.format.wrappingColumn` (or possibly any other known doc type, though I mostly just care about markdown) to control this per type.

data.title: Cmd+C/Ctrl+C doesn't reach web view
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use the command 'vscode.previewHtml' in our extension, like the sample code [vscode preview html sample](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/blob/master/previewhtml-sample/src/extension.ts).
2. In another panel will display the previewed html.

However, we can't copy the text from the previewed html in our test, even in the sample extension [Preview CSS Properties Sample](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=eg2.vscode-css-properties).

And I think we may have the requirements that, user wish to copy the text(maybe the previewed result is transformed output) in the preview panel.
